citation.article-title: Fervidobacterium islandicum sp. nov., a new extremely thermophilic eubacterium belonging to the "Thermotogales"

p.s: Description of Fervidobacterium islandicum, sp. nov. Huber, Woese, Langworthy, Kristjansson and Stetter sp. nov.
Fervidobacterium islandicum (is.la'n.di.cum M. L. neutr, adj. islandicum, describing its place of isolation)
Cells are Gram-negative rods, occurring singly and in pairs about 1 to 4 μm long (main size: 1.8 μm) and 0.6 μm wide, forming blebs ("spheroids") at one end.
Often found in aggregates of up to 50 cells.
Sometimes rods are surrounded by a spheroid or are in chains of up to 6 cells.
Motile.
White round colonies formed on agar.
Growth between 50 and 80°C with an optimum at 65°C (doubling time: 75 rain.), pH of growth between 6.0 and 8.0 with an optimum at around 7.
No growth in medium containing 25% sea water.
Yeast extract is required for growth.
Addition of pyruvate, ribose, glucose, maltose, raffinose, starch, and cellulose stimulates growth.
On glucose, L(+)lactate, acetate, ethanol, H2, CO2 and traces of isobutyric and isovaleric acid are formed.
Growth strictly anaerobic.
H2 inhibits growth.
Reduction of S°.
Cells do not grow in the presence of vancomycin, ampicillin, streptomycin, chloramphenicol, and rifampicin (10 μg/ml).
Sensitive to lysozyme.
No m-DAP present.
No serological cross-reaction with Thermotoga maritima RNA polymerase antiserum.
C28 to C34-dicarboxylic fatty acids present.
The DNA base composition is about 40 mol % G+C.
No significant DNA homology with Fervidobacterium nodosum.
Single strain isolated from a neutral hot spring with low salinity at Hveragerði (Iceland).
Type strain is Fervidobacterium islandicum, H 21, DSM 5733, Braunschweig, FRG.
